title: Quiz 3: Interlocutory Applications & Injunctions
description: Evaluate your understanding of interim orders, injunctions, and the specific principles governing them.

questions.question: Which leading case established the three conditions for granting an interlocutory injunction in Kenya?

options.text: American Cyanamid Co v Ethicon Ltd
Giella v Cassman Brown & Co Ltd
Donoghue v Stevenson
Rylands v Fletcher

questions.explanation: Giella v Cassman Brown [1973] EA 358 is the locus classicus in Kenya setting the three conditions: prima facie case, irreparable injury, and balance of convenience.

questions.question: According to Giella v Cassman Brown, what must an applicant show to obtain an interlocutory injunction? (Select all that apply)

options.text: A prima facie case with a probability of success.
Proof beyond reasonable doubt.
That damages would not be an adequate remedy (irreparable injury).
That the balance of convenience favors granting the injunction.

questions.explanation: The three pillars are: Prima facie case, Irreparable injury, and Balance of convenience.

questions.question: A Mareva Injunction is used to allow a plaintiff to search a defendant's premises for evidence.
questions.explanation: A Mareva Injunction freezes assets to prevent dissipation. An Anton Piller Order is used for search and seizure of evidence.

questions.question: An ___BLANK___ order allows an applicant to enter a defendant's premises to search for and seize incriminating evidence that might otherwise be destroyed.
questions.explanation: Named after the case Anton Piller KG v Manufacturing Processes Ltd, this order prevents destruction of evidence.
questions.hint: It's a draconian 'search' order named after a case.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a purpose of Interlocutory Applications?

options.text: To maintain the status quo pending trial.
To finally determine the substantive rights of the parties.
To prevent abuse of the court process.
To protect the subject matter of the suit.

questions.explanation: Interlocutory applications are temporary measures. They do not finally determine the substantive rights; that is done at the main trial.

questions.question: Match the Interim Order with its primary function:
questions.explanation: Injunctions stop/compel acts; Receivers manage property; Security protects against cost loss; Commissions gather evidence.
questions.hint: Match the remedy to the problem it solves.

questions.question: In an ex parte application for an injunction, what is the specific duty imposed on the applicant regarding facts?
questions.explanation: The applicant must make full and frank disclosure of all material facts, including those adverse to their case, because the other party is absent.
questions.hint: They must tell the whole truth, even the bad parts.

questions.question: Under Order 40, what is the maximum duration for an ex parte temporary injunction before it must be heard inter partes?

options.text: 7 days
14 days
30 days
Until the suit is determined

questions.explanation: Order 40 Rule 4 limits ex parte injunctions to 14 days, renewable only once.

questions.question: An injunction can be issued against the Government of Kenya to restrain it from performing a statutory duty.
questions.explanation: Section 16 of the Government Proceedings Act generally prohibits injunctions against the Government. The court issues a declaratory order instead.
questions.hint: Does the Government have immunity from injunctions?

questions.question: Which of the following are grounds for striking out pleadings? (Select all that apply)

options.text: It discloses no reasonable cause of action.
It is scandalous, frivolous, or vexatious.
The case is weak and unlikely to succeed.
It is an abuse of the process of the court.

questions.explanation: Order 2 Rule 15 lists specific grounds: no cause of action, scandalous/frivolous, abuse of process. A 'weak case' is a matter for trial, not striking out.
questions.hint: Think about defects in the pleading itself, not just the strength of evidence.
